introPages.title: What is inversion?
introPages.body:
When a sentence begins with a negative or restrictive word, the subject and auxiliary invert – the auxiliary comes before the subject, like in a question.

Normal: I have never seen. Inverted: Never have I seen.

Normal: He left. Inverted: Not only did he leave.

In Part 2, the gap often needs the auxiliary (have, has, had, do, does, did, can, will, would, etc.) that completes the inverted structure.

introPages.title: Trigger words
introPages.body:
These words at the start of a sentence trigger inversion:

Negatives: never, hardly, scarcely, seldom, rarely, little, nowhere

Restrictives: not only, only when, only then, only after, no sooner, under no circumstances, in no way, at no time

introPages.title: Which auxiliary?
introPages.body:
Perfect tenses: use have, has, had. Never have I seen. Hardly had she arrived when …. No sooner had he left than …

Present/past simple: add do, does, did. Not only did he leave. Rarely do we see. Seldom does she speak.

Modal or other auxiliary already present: that auxiliary inverts. Under no circumstances should you go. Only then could we start.

introPages.title: Fixed patterns
introPages.body:
Hardly / scarcely … when (not than): Hardly had she arrived when the phone rang.

No sooner … than (not when): No sooner had he left than it began to rain.

Not only … but also: Not only did he leave, but he also took the keys.

Only when / only then + inversion in the main clause: Only when he left did I realise.

introPages.title: Rules for the gap
introPages.body:
• Sentence starts with a negative/restrictive word? → expect inversion; the gap often needs the auxiliary.
  • Perfect meaning (have/has/had + past participle)? → use have, has, or had.
  • Present or past simple? → add do, does, or did.
  • Check the paired word: hardly … when; no sooner … than.

mcQuiz.question: In Never ___ I seen such a thing, which auxiliary fits?
mcQuiz.explanation: Never have I seen – perfect tense, use 'have'.

mcQuiz.question: In Not only ___ he leave, but he also took the keys, which auxiliary fits?
mcQuiz.explanation: Present/past simple needs do/does/did. 'Leave' is base form → did.

mcQuiz.question: In Hardly had she arrived ___ the phone rang, which word fits?
In No sooner had he left ___ it began to rain, which word fits?
In Rarely ___ we see such behaviour, which auxiliary fits?
mcQuiz.explanation: Present simple → add 'do'. Rarely do we see.

mcQuiz.question: In Under no circumstances ___ you go, which auxiliary fits?
mcQuiz.explanation: With modals, the modal inverts. Under no circumstances should you go.

mcQuiz.question: In Only when he left ___ I realise, which auxiliary fits?
mcQuiz.explanation: Past simple in main clause → did. Only when he left did I realise.

shortQuestions.question: Never I have seen such a thing.
accepted: never have i seen such a thing
shortQuestions.explanation: Subject and auxiliary must invert. Never have I seen.

shortQuestions.question: Not only he left, but he also took the keys.
accepted: not only did he leave, but he also took the keys
shortQuestions.explanation: Past simple needs 'did' + base form. Not only did he leave.

shortQuestions.question: Hardly she had arrived when the phone rang.
accepted: hardly had she arrived when the phone rang
shortQuestions.explanation: Auxiliary (had) goes before subject. Hardly had she arrived.

shortQuestions.question: No sooner he had left than it began to rain.
accepted: no sooner had he left than it began to rain
shortQuestions.explanation: Auxiliary (had) goes before subject. No sooner had he left.

shortQuestions.question: Rarely we see such behaviour.
accepted: rarely do we see such behaviour
shortQuestions.explanation: Present simple needs 'do'. Rarely do we see.

shortQuestions.question: Under no circumstances you should go there.
accepted: under no circumstances should you go there
under no circumstances should you go
shortQuestions.explanation: Modal (should) inverts before subject. Under no circumstances should you go.

shortQuestions.question: Only when he left I realised the truth.
accepted: only when he left did i realise the truth
only when he left did i realise
shortQuestions.explanation: Main clause needs inversion. Past simple → did. Only when he left did I realise.

optionalQuestionsBank.question: Why do we invert after words like 'never' and 'not only'?
optionalQuestionsBank.suggested: Inversion adds emphasis and is required in formal/written English when these words begin the sentence. The structure mirrors a question: auxiliary + subject.

optionalQuestionsBank.question: When do we use 'have' vs 'do' in inverted structures?
optionalQuestionsBank.suggested: Use have/has/had when the meaning is perfect (have seen, had arrived). Use do/does/did when the main verb is present or past simple (did leave, do see).

optionalQuestionsBank.question: What is the difference between 'hardly … when' and 'no sooner … than'?
optionalQuestionsBank.suggested: Both mean 'as soon as'. Hardly/scarcely pairs with 'when'. No sooner pairs with 'than'. Hardly had she arrived when ... / No sooner had he left than ...

optionalQuestionsBank.question: In 'Only when he left did I realise', why is it 'did I realise' not 'I realised'?
optionalQuestionsBank.suggested: When 'only when' (or only then, only after) starts the sentence, the main clause must invert. Past simple needs 'did' + base form: did I realise.

optionalQuestionsBank.question: Give three negative or restrictive expressions that trigger inversion.
optionalQuestionsBank.suggested: e.g. Never, Not only, Hardly, Rarely, Seldom, Under no circumstances, No sooner, Only when, Little did I know.
